Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium," a conference series in which the 2018 event will take place during May 29-June 2, 2018, on the campus of Miami University in Oxford, Ohio. Additional information about the conference can be found on the website https://users.miamioh.edu/mckennp2/gpots/index.html

The Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (GPOTS) is an annual regional conference that has taken place since 1981. It brings together a diverse group of mathematicians whose primary research interest is in operator algebras, operator theory and related areas. A sampling of the topics presented in the 2018 event is given by the following: the corona problem, Hilbert modules, noncommutative function theory, deformation rigidity, free probability, subfactors and fusion categories, classification of C*-algebras, C*-algebras and dynamical systems, the Baum-Connes conjecture, noncommutative differential geometry, index theory, operator spaces and applications, and logic and operator algebras. The expected attendance is between 100 and 150 participants. The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The annual meeting of the Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (GPOTS) was held on the campus of Miami University, Oxford OH on May 29-June 2, 2018.  The conference was funded by the Department of Mathematics at Miami University and National Science Foundation grant DMS-1764137.  The members of the Organizing Committee were Caleb Eckhardt (Miami), Paul McKenney (Miami) and Narcisse Randrianantoanina (Miami).

Speakers: The meeting featured fifteen plenary speakers with national and international reputations.

1. Ionut Chifan (University of Iowa)

2. Marius Dadarlat (Purdue University)

3. Ilijas Farah (York University)

4. Nigel Higson (Penn State University)

5. Marius Junge (University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign)

6. Matthew Kennedy (University of Waterloo)

7. Piotr Nowak (IMPAN and University of Warsaw)

8. Judith Packer (University of Colorado at Boulder)

9. David Penneys (Ohio State University)

10. Jesse Peterson (Vanderbilt University)

11. Anna Skripka (University of New Mexico)

12. Robin Tucker-Drob (Texas A&M)

13. Rufus Willett (University of Hawai'i)

14. Wilhelm Winter (University of M?nster)

15. Quanhua Xu (Universit? de Franche-Comt?)

Each plenary lecture was 50 minutes long. In addition to the plenary lectures, there were 58 contributed talks, each 20 minutes long; fourteen of these were given by graduate students.

 

Demographic Information: There were 126 attendees at the meeting, including the three organizers.  Here is a breakdown in terms of gender and position: 

Gender:

  • Female ? 21
  • Male ? 105

Position:

  •  Faculty (tenured, tenure track, instructor) ? 66
  • Postdoctoral Fellow ? 16
  • Graduate Student ? 44

The conference participants represented nine countries, 19 states, and 55 institutions of higher learning. 

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2019
Modified by: Caleb Eckhardt
